primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in the state of human death and hopelessness to reconstitute life and identity by His own initiative.

tekstueel_bewijs: I will cause breath to enter you
I will put my Spirit within you
I have done it, says the Lord
He is able to give life

object.identificatie: Life, Resurrection, and the Knowledge of God's Lordship
tekstueel_bewijs: you shall know that I am the Lord

zender.identificatie: The Nature of God (The One who raises the dead)
tekstueel_bewijs: It proceeds from his nature as the one who raises the dead

ontvanger.identificatie: The 'Whole House of Israel' / The Hearer / Humanity in Exile
tekstueel_bewijs: you who are in this congregation

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit / The Word of the Lord
tekstueel_bewijs: in the power of the same Spirit
now hear de Word of de Lord
our hope is lost; we are clean cut off
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Death is described as 'nothing more true' and 'nothing more terrible,' a power no human trick can dispel.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of faith and endurance in the face of death (exemplified by Moltke).
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer (Moltke/Martha/Hearer)
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Confession of faith / Resistance to evil
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The human action is a 'small decision' made because God has already 'taken all the trouble' with the subject.

voorbeelden_god_subject: I will cause breath to enter you
God raises them from the dust
The Lord took all that trouble
voorbeelden_mens_subject: The Israelites have done less than nothing

voorbeelden: you shall know that I am the Lord
everything... acquires its meaning in retrospect
he is able to give life
death can have no dominion over him

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on God's 'Ability' (Pouvoir) in the face of human 'Inability' (Death).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From S2 (Death) to ~S2 (Hopelessness/Dry Bones) to S1 (Resurrection) via the Word of the Lord.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ is the 'More True' reality that negates the finality of S2.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; death is not trivialized but faced as an absolute human end.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon explicitly denies human merit ('done less than nothing') and places all causative action on God's nature.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: He made small decisions and took limited actions

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: The promise is unconditional. God’s action... is not a reward due them.
For this one hour the Lord took all that trouble.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Moltke is used as an example, but his heroism is framed as God's 'work' on a 'humble earthen vessel.'
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides this: Martha is not a hero of faith but a recipient of a revelation.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and awe; shifting from the 'dread of dying' to the 'Word of the Lord.'
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic restoration of the human subject.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'dry bones' of Israel to the 'dead Lazarus' to the 'martyred Moltke' is perfectly unified by the theme of God's life-giving power.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'unresting death' as a 'truth' and Christ as 'more true'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Death can have no dominion over him.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit provides the 'Pouvoir' (Power) to live and believe where the human is 'dry bones'.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Total; described as being 'clean cut off' and 'dead'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is a masterclass in theocentric narrative. God is the Subject of all primary salvific verbs.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is appropriate for a Lent/Resurrection sermon.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon avoids the trap of 'exemplarism' by grounding human courage entirely in God's prior act of 'taking trouble' with the individual.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis would focus on the Larkin poem's pathos; Greimas shows that the poem functions as the 'Opponent' in the actantial structure.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains Ezekiel's context; Greimas shows that Ezekiel's 'God' is the same functional Subject as the 'Jesus' of John 11.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'unconditional' nature of the promise is a structural necessity when the Receiver is defined as 'Dry Bones' (incapable of being a Subject).

appendices.notities: The sermon successfully navigates the 'Rutledge Rule' by making God the subject of the active verbs of transformation.
